tag: html body text h2 span
content: Trapping Regulations

tag: html body text p strong span
content: Definition of Trapping

tag: html body text p span
content: To trap means to take, kill or capture wildlife with traps, deadfalls and other devices commonly used to take wildlife, including the shooting or killing of lawfully trapped animals. It also includes all related activities such as placing, setting, staking or checking traps or assisting another person with these activities.

tag: html body text h3 a span
content: Rights of Trappers

tag: html body text ul li span
content: No one may disturb a trap lawfully set by another person.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: No one may remove a lawfully trapped animal from another person's trap.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: No one may harass a trapper while he or she is trapping.

tag: html body text h3 a span
content: Trapper Education Course

tag: html body text p span
content: Required for persons who have never possessed a trapping license. The trapping course is at least 8 hours in length and is free. For information on trapper education courses in your area, contact the nearest

tag: html body text p a span
content: DEC regional Sportsman Ed Coordinator

tag: html body text p span
html body text h3 a span
content: Legal Traps

tag: html body text ul li a span
content: Trigger Regulations

tag: html body text ul li span
content: for body-gripping traps used in the Southern Zone for beaver

tag: html body text ul li span
content: How to

tag: html body text ul li a span
content: Measure Traps

tag: html body text ul li span
content: You must put your name and address on all your traps.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Foothold traps larger than 4 inches set on land must have a pan tension device and be covered when set.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Teeth are not allowed on foothold traps.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: On land, foothold traps must be 5 3/4 inches or smaller.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: During beaver or otter season, foothold traps up to 7 1/4 inches are allowed if set under water.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: When the beaver or otter season is closed, foothold traps set in water for mink or muskrat may not be larger than 5 3/4 inches.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: A foothold trap larger than 7 1/4 inches is never legal to use.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Body-gripping traps more than 7 1/2 inches may never be used on land.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Body-gripping traps more than 7 1/2 inches may only be used in water during an open beaver or otter season.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Snares cannot be used for trapping.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Box or cage traps are legal for all species.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: You cannot use a cage trap that is designed to take more than one muskrat at a setting.

tag: html body text h3 a span
content: Trapping Methods

tag: html body text div p strong span
content: Land

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You may not set a trap in such a manner that it causes a captured animal to be fully suspended in the air.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You may not set a trap on a public road. You are allowed to set a trap in a culvert or ditch unless the property is posted or the landowner does not allow trapping.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Foothold traps larger than 4 inches must be covered when set on land.

tag: html body text div p strong span
content: Water

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You may set a trap in a permanent body of water only when the mink, muskrat, otter, or beaver season is open.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You may not disturb a beaver lodge, beaver dam, or muskrat house or den.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Traps may not be set on or within 15 feet of a beaver lodge at any time.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Traps may not be set on or within 15 feet of a beaver dam except during an open otter season.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You may not set a trap on or within 5 feet of a muskrat house.

tag: html body text div p strong span
content: Land or Water

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You may use any legal method to kill a trapped animal. You do not need a hunting license to use a firearm to kill a legally trapped animal.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You may not set or stake a trap prior to 7:00 a.m. on opening day.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You are not allowed to set a trap within 100 feet of a house, school, playground or church unless you have permission from the owner of the land where the trap is set.

tag: html body text h3 a span
content: Checking Traps

tag: html body text p span
content: Traps must be checked at least once in each 24 hours except:

tag: html body text ul li span
content: If you are trapping in WMUs 5C, 5F, 5G, 5H, 5J, 6F, 6J, or 6N, traps must be checked at least once in each 48 hours.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: If you are trapping for beaver, otter, mink or muskrat in WMUs 5A, 6A, 6C, 6G or 6H, traps set in water must be checked at least once in each 48 hours.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Written descriptions of

tag: html body text ul li a span
content: Wildlife Management Units

tag: html body text ul li span
content: are available using this link.

tag: html body text h3 a span
content: Pelt Sealing

tag: html body text p span
content: Beaver, otter, bobcat, fisher and marten must have a plastic seal attached to the pelt or unskinned animal before:

tag: html body text ul li span
content: It is sold or ownership is transferred to another person, or

tag: html body text ul li span
content: It is mounted or tanned, or

tag: html body text ul li span
content: It leaves New York State, or

tag: html body text ul li span
content: 10 days have passed since the close of the season where the fur was taken.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: The plastic pelt seals can be removed when the pelt is processed for taxidermy, tanning or manufacturing.

tag: html body text p span
content: Here is how you get your pelts sealed. It is a 2 step process.

tag: html body text div p strong span
content: Step 1—

tag: html body text div p span
content: Filling out your furbearer possession tag

tag: html body text div p a span
content: Click for printable tag.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: A possession tag must be filled out for each animal you take.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Possession tags must be filled out immediately after you reach your motor vehicle, camp or home, whichever comes first.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Possession tags must stay with the animal or pelt at all times but they do not need to be attached to the pelt.

tag: html body text div p strong span
content: Step 2—

tag: html body text div p span
content: Getting your pelt sealed All Species

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: A completed furbearer possession tag must be submitted to obtain a plastic pelt seal.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You can give your pelts to another person (other than a taxidermist) so he or she can get the pelts sealed or get them skinned. You must give that person your trapping license or a copy of your license and your completed possession tags while he or she has your pelts.

tag: html body text div p span
content: Beaver

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Furbearer possession tags for beaver can be submitted by mail, FAX (518) 402-8925 or in person.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: You also may report a beaver using the

tag: html body text div ul li a span
content: DECALS

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: call-in system. Call 1-866-GAME-RPT.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Once you have submitted your possession tag(s) for beaver you will be sent or given the plastic pelt seal(s) and instructions.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Immediately upon receipt of seal(s), you must attach the seal(s) to the pelt(s).

tag: html body text div p span
content: Otter, Bobcat, Fisher and Marten

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Only authorized Department representatives can attach the plastic pelt seals to otter, bobcat, fisher or marten.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Call the regional

tag: html body text div ul li a span
content: wildlife office

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: to make arrangements to get your otter, bobcat, fisher, or marten sealed.

tag: html body text div ul li span
content: Prior to having a marten sealed, you must submit the entire carcass.

tag: html body text h3 a span
content: Coyote Reporting

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Report your coyote by calling the DECALS call-in system. Call 1-866-GAMERPT (1-866-426-3778).

tag: html body text ul li span
content: You may use the furbearer Possession Tag to write down the information before you call.

tag: html body text h3 a span
content: Buying and Selling Fur

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Species requiring a pelt seal cannot be bought or sold or given to another person unless it has the plastic pelt seal on it. All other species may be bought, sold, and transported without restriction.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: Furbearers may be bought or sold either skinned or unskinned.

tag: html body text ul li span
content: People who buy fur do not need a fur buyer's license in New York.

tag: html body text p a span
content: Back to top of page
